title: Territorial Acknowledgement
text:
The University of British Columbia and the city of Vancouver are on the traditional, ancestral, and unceded territory of the Coast Salish Peoples. Specifically the UBC Vancouver campus is on xʷməθkʷəy̓əm (Musqueam) land.

There are nearly 200 First Nations spread through BC, and many more across the continent.

It is essential to recognize Indigenous territories and Indigenous sovereignty, especially within the context of geography courses.
To learn more about the Indigenous people, culture, and languages where you live and around the world, check out native-land.ca.





Map Source





Why Do an Acknowledgement?
A land acknowledgement is meant to convey a deep rooted cultural connection to the land and the historical and present day injustices and violence enacted on Indigenous communities through colonialism. For centuries, settler societies have perpetuated a genocide against Indigenous people across the globe. In many ways this genocide is still ongoing here in British Columbia and across Canada. There has been concerted effort by the government, religious organizations, and educational institutions to erase Indigenous culture and identity which as marginalized these communities in Canadian Society.

An acknowledgement is one small way to help with that, but it cannot be treated as a formality. It is a time to reflect and build understanding.



What does it mean?


Traditional and Ancestral Recognize by whom the lands were traditionally used and/or occupied and the cultures have been handed down from generation to generation. The area around UBC was used by many different people, including the xʷməθkʷəy̓əm, əl̓ilwətaɁɬ, and Skwxwú7mesh-ulh Nations.
These people are are part of a broader linguistic / cultural group of Coast Salish speaking people. The xʷməθkʷəy̓əm and əl̓ilwətaɁɬ speak dialects of Hul’q’umi’num’ / Halq’eméylem / hən̓q̓əmin̓əm̓ and the Skwxwú7mesh-ulh speak Sḵwx̱wú7mesh sníchim.







Unceded: Refers to land that was not turned over to the government by a treaty or other agreement. Over 95% of the land in BC, and many lands elsewhere in the world were never ceded by treaty. Without treaties, these lands remain the sovereign territory of the First Nations that call them home. Yet at the same time, the lands have been claimed by Canada and these First Nations living on these lands lack a framework to express their sovereignty. This by no means absolves the Canadian government of their crimes where lands were “ceded” by treaty. Treaties were more frequently reached by coercion than negotiation. The RCMP was created specifically to force indigenous people off their lands by any means necessary.

text:
History and Scope of the Station
The UBC Climatological Station was established in 1957 at UBC Point Grey Campus west of the Agronomy Barn on Agronomy Road. By 1961 the UBC Climatological Station had achieved the necessary standards to be classed as an Ordinary Climatological Station by the Environment Canada Climatological Network (Hare and Thomas, 1979). In the early 1970s, campus development forced its relocation further south, to the Totem Research Station (Figure 2). The station is located 100m a.s.l. with an open exposure to the majority of the climatic elements.






Figure 2: Location of Totem Climate Station



Standardization
Any site of a climatological station must meet basic criteria before its data will be accepted by Environment Canada. For example, the surroundings must be reasonably flat, there should be no major obstacles to airflow, no significant obstruction to the horizon, no extraneous sources of heat, vapor or dust and the surface should consist of short grass. Similarly, the instrumentation must conform to Environment Canada standards. The data gathered from a climatological station are to be related to large-scale air mass and regional characteristics not the microclimate of the site. Insistence on these points assures users of site and instrument standardization so that different stations can be compared within expected limits of accuracy.

Radiation
Figure 3 (a) shows a pyranometer, which is used to measure the short-wave (SW) radiation at the station. Shortwave radiation is also know as solar radiation, because it is the primary wavelength of radiation emitted from the Sun. The pyranometer contains a small black absorber disk inside a glass dome whose radiative properties allow only radiation with wavelengths (\(\mu\)) between 0.3 and 3 \(\mu m\) to pass through. As radiation reaches the absorber disk, it will warm up and create a temperature difference to the rest of the body of the instrument whose temperature varies only slowly. The difference can be directly related to short-wave receipt.
Figure 3 (b) shows a pyrgeometer, which is used to measure the thermal radiation, also know as long-wave (LW) radiation. It works in a similar way as a pyranometer, except it measures wavelengths between 4.5 and 100 µm. Figure 3 (c) shows how sets of pyranometers and pyrgeometers, one of each pointing upward toward the sky and downward toward the ground, are used to measure both incoming and outgoing short-wave and long-wave radiation respectively. Air temperature and humidity are measured in a Stevenson screen Figure 4 designed to protect the instruments from liquid water (rain/snow) and shade them from solar radiation, but permit free air circulation.

Soil temperatures are measured using Copper/Constantan thermocouples. These are wires made up of two different metals that carry a small electrical signal. The transfer of electricity between the two metals is dependent upon temperature, and from that we can calculate temperature for whatever medium the thermocouple is in contact with.

Precipitation
Rainfall is measured using a tipping bucket Figure 6 (b), which works by funneling precipitation into small seesaw-like counter Figure 6. The depth of new snowfall and the total depth of the snow lying on the ground was historically measured with a meter stick. It is now measured using an automated sonic snow depth sensor Figure 6 (c).

Liquid water equivalent of the snow is typically estimated using a 10:1 ratio

10 mm of snow ≈ 1 mm of rainfall

However, this is just an average, and accuracy of this estimate can vary drastically depending on the type of snow.

In Vancouver, we typically get “wet, heavy snow” which has a much higher liquid water equivalent, with a ratio closer to 5:1. Using the standard 10:1 ratio for a typical Vancouver snowfall would underestimate liquid precipitation.
“Powder”, the light, fluffy snow common in dry mountainous areas that makes for great skiing has a much lower liquid water equivalent, with a ratio closer to 20:1.

title: Lab 2: Radiation
text:
Net Radiation
These four components together constitute Net All-Wave Radiation (\(R_n\)), which is defined the sum of all radiation components Equation 1.
\[
R_n = (SW \downarrow - SW \uparrow) + (LW \downarrow - LW \uparrow)
\tag{1}\]
Short-wave (aka solar) radiation is emitted from the sun. Climate of an ecosystem is largely determined by the amount of incoming short wave radiation (\(SW \downarrow\)) that reaches the ecosystem and the proportion of that radiation that is absorbed (\(a\)) by the plant, soil and water surfaces versus the portion that is reflected (\(\alpha\)) by the surface.

When \(SW \downarrow\) that is absorbed by the earth’s surface, it is re-emitted by the surface as long-wave radiation (\(LW \uparrow\)), aka (aka thermal radiation). Figure 1 highlights the difference between short-wave radiation (emitted by the sun) and long-wave radiation (emitted by the earth).

A portion of \(SW \downarrow\) is reflected by the earths surface back towards the sky, this is known as outgoing, or reflected short-wave radiation (\(SW \uparrow\)).
Net Radiation can describe how much energy is entering or leaving a given area. Incoming short-wave \((\downarrow SW)\) is measured by a pyranometer pointing up to the sky and short-wave radiation outgoing (reflected) from the underlying surface \((\uparrow SW)\) is measured by a pyranometer pointed at the ground. Likewise, incoming long-wave radiation \((\downarrow LW)\) is measured by a pyrgeometer pointing up to the sky and outgoing (emitted) long-wave radiation \((\uparrow LW)\) is measured by a pyrgeometer pointing at the ground. Knowing the four radiation components, we can then calculate net radiation \((R_n)\). Net radiation can tell us how much energy is entering (positive) or leaving (negative) the site at any given time. If net \((R_n)\) is a large positive number, that indicates significant energy input, which would cause the land surface at the site to warm up. Conversely, if \((R_n)\) is negative, that means the site is loosing energy (cooling off).



Figure 1: Simplified comparison of short wave and long wave radiation as they relate to the emissions from the Sun and the Earth.


Tropical climates are hot because they receive ample \(SW \downarrow\) all year long. Polar climates are cold because they receive very little \(SW \downarrow\) over the course of a year, and much of the \(SW \downarrow\) they do receive is reflected as \(SW \uparrow\) by snowy surfaces.

title: Lab 2: Radiation
text:
Theory
All radiation striking a surface or an object must be either absorbed, transmitted, or reflected:
\[
a_\lambda + \tau_\lambda + \alpha_\lambda = 1
\tag{2}\]
The coefficients of absorption (absorptivity \(a_\lambda\)), transmission (transmissivity \(\tau_\lambda\)), and reflection (reflectivity \(\alpha_\lambda\)) are not the same for all kinds of radiation. Their values depend on the wavelength \(\lambda\) of the incident radiation (e.g., difference between wavelengths from a fluorescent and incandescent lamp). When talking specifically about \(\alpha_{SW}\) (reflected short wave radiation), we can also define the term albedo, the coefficient of reflection for short wave radiation:
\[
albedo = \alpha_{SW} = \frac{\uparrow SW}{\downarrow SW}
\tag{3}\]
Given the definition for albedo (\(\alpha\)), we can also re-define \(SW\uparrow = \alpha_{SW} SW\uparrow\) and therefore, rewrite Equation 1 as:
\[
R_n = (1-\alpha_{SW})SW\downarrow + (LW\downarrow - LW\uparrow)
\tag{4}\]

Note: This definition works because the earth’s surface is not a source of short-wave radiation; it can reflect \(SW\), but it does not emit \(SW\).




Figure 3: Spectral absorptivity, reflectivity and transmissivity of a poplar leaf


To describe a radiation source, we can plot its spectrum. Spectra for solar radiation and radiation from a fluorescent lamp and an incandescent tungsten filament lamp are shown in Figure 2. In this diagram, the spectra have been adjusted to equal peak heights.
Plant leaves have interesting radiative properties that are part of the plants’ adaptation to their environments. The coefficients of reflection, transmission and absorption are strongly dependent on wavelength as shown by a typical example in Figure 3. Energy is strongly absorbed in the visible region where radiation is active in photosynthesis. In the near infrared region (NIR) radiation is more strongly reflected and transmitted. The reflectivity and absorptivity of soils and animal coats are also dependent on wavelength.
Units of wavelength are often given in micrometers (1 \(\mu m\) = 10-6 m). Radiation energy flux density can be measured by sensors that produce electrical signals. In this laboratory the selenium photocell produces a voltage that is proportional to the flux of shortwave radiation striking the sensor. The sensor is not sensitive to longwave radiation. The selenium photocell has its maximum (peak) response at \(\lambda\) = 0.5 \(\mu m\).

title: Lab 3: Atmospheric Humidity
text:
Theory
The most common type of instrument used to measure humidity is the psychrometer. This consists simply of a pair of thermometers, one of which has a wetted wick enclosing the sensor. The wet-bulb is cooled by evaporation to a temperature that depends on the atmospheric vapor density.
The water vapor density \(\rho_v\) (= absolute humidity) can be calculated from measurements of wet- and dry-bulb temperatures using the relationship:
\[
\rho_v = \rho^*_{vw}(T_w) - \gamma(T-T_w)
\tag{1}\]
These and other symbols in this exercise are defined in Table 5.1. The density of water vapor in the atmosphere \(\rho_v(T)\), is the basic measure of atmospheric moisture. It is the mass of water vapor in unit volume of air (Units: kg m-3 but often given in g m-3 to make more sensibly sized numbers).
Other ways of expressing the amount of moisture are used and each has particular usefulness in certain applications. The total amount of water that the atmosphere can hold without condensation depends only on temperature. This quantity, called the saturation vapor density ^*_v(T), is given for a range of temperatures in Table 3. The ratio of actual vapor density to the maximum possible (i.e. the saturation vapor density) when expressed as a percentage is called the relative humidity:
\[
RH = \frac{\rho_v}{\rho^*_v(T)}
\tag{2}\]
For some calculations of evaporation rate, the difference between the maximum and the actual vapor density is useful. This is called the vapor density deficit:
\[
VDD = \rho^*_v(T) - \rho_v
\tag{3}\]
We may express the water vapor content of air by finding the temperature to which a parcel of air could be cooled at constant atmospheric pressure before condensation commences. This temperature is called the dew point temperature \(T_d\). Note: that for a saturated parcel the dewpoint temperature is the temperature of the parcel. For any water vapor density, \(T_d\) can be found by using Table 3 in reverse. For example, air with a vapor density of 7.8 g m-3 has a \(T_d\) of 7°C.
Water vapor content of the air can be expressed in terms of the partial pressure exerted by the water vapor, or water vapor pressure, \(e\). This is related to vapor density by the gas law as follows:
\[
e = \rho_v R_v T
\tag{4}\]
Where R_v is the gas constant for water vapor (4.62 ×10-4 kPa m3 g-1 K-1) and T is the absolute temperature (K). Using units of g m-3 for \(\rho_v(T)\) results in units of kPa (kilopascals) for \(e\).
Saturation vapor pressure, \(e*(T)\): Consider a parcel at temperature \(T\). Unless the parcel is currently saturated, the parcel could hold more water vapor than it currently does. The partial pressure exerted by the water vapor is given by \(e\), whereas the partial pressure that would be exerted by the water vapor if the parcel were saturated, is e*, which is a function of temperature: i.e., \(e*(T)\). (Units: kPa).
Vapor pressure deficit, VPD: Vapor pressure deficit represents the difference between the actual and saturation vapor pressures of a parcel at temperature T:
\[
VPD = e*(T) - e
\tag{5}\]

Note: that the smaller the VPD, the closer the parcel is to saturation. (Units: kPa)

title: Lab 4: Atmospheric Stability & The Planetary Boundary Layer
text:
Theory
The environmental lapse rate (ELR) is the actual rate of air temperature decrease or increase with height in the atmosphere, i.e. as measured by thermometers at different heights. The daily average ELR is typically about 0.006 K m-1 but may vary considerably.
The dry adiabatic lapse rate (Γd) is the temperature change of a dry (unsaturated) air parcel as the parcel moves up for down in the atmosphere. This is a process lapse rate. The parcel is assumed not to mix with the environment but allowed to change its volume - it is said to behave adiabatically. Γd is a constant with a value of 0.01 K m-1.
If you look at the difference between those two lapse rates - ELR vs. Γd - you can assess the static stability of a particular air layer:
ELR > Γd: unstable. For an air parcel, a slight upward displacement will result in a continuous rise of the parcel because the parcel will become warmer and less dense than the surrounding air at the same height and therefore possesses buoyancy. Conversely, if the air parcel is displaced below, it will become cooler and more dense than the surrounding air at the same height, and it will tend to continue sinking. In an unstable layer, vertical movements are enhanced.
ELR = Γd: neutral. There will be no tendency for a parcel to rise or sink after it is displaced either above or below because it cools or warms at exactly the same rate as the surrounding air. Therefore, the parcel will come to rest after the displacing force is removed.
ELR < Γd: stable. If an air parcel is displaced upwards, it will become cooler and more dense than the surrounding air and tend to sink back to its original location. If displaced below, it will find itself warmer and tend to rise back up to its original location. In a stable layer, vertical movements are suppressed. In very stable conditions, smoke and other air pollutants accumulate and often cause respiratory problems.
To facilitate comparison between the ELR and the dry adiabatic lapse rate, atmospheric scientists prefer to convert environmental (measured) temperatures T at a particular height z to potential temperatures θ by:
\[
\theta(z) = T(z) + \Gamma_d z                           
\tag{1}\]
Note: θ(z) is the potential temperature at height z and T(z) is the temperature at height z. No need to multiply them by z.
Potential temperatures have the advantage that we can easily determine the stability of a layer on a graph: a decreasing potential temperature with height indicates an unstable layer, a constant potential temperature with height indicates a neutral layer, and an increasing potential temperature with height indicates a stable layer. This is true because the dry adiabatic lapse rate, Γd, plots as a vertical line on a graph of potential temperature vs. height (by definition).
The layer of air closest to the Earth’s surface - the planetary boundary layer (PBL) - changes its vertical temperature distribution often throughout the 24-hour diurnal cycle because here air temperature is strongly affected by surface conditions. The PBL is modified during the day by radiative heating of the surface, which generates buoyancy and warms up the lower atmosphere, resulting in typically unstable conditions close to the ground. The daytime boundary layer is termed the mixed layer whose depth h* may be defined as the height to which buoyant dry air parcels rise adiabatically.
At night, radiative cooling of the ground surface indicates that the atmosphere close to the ground will cool down as well, and the near-surface air becomes stable. Therefore, the mixed layer is largely destroyed at night and is replaced at low-level by a stable inversion layer.

Theory: The surface energy balance is a fundamental budget approach that describes the energy exchange at surface-atmosphere interfaces. It is based on the conservation equation of energy that says that energy can neither be created or destroyed by any ordinary means. The surface energy balance is essential to estimate evaporative water loss, cooling rates, growing conditions, frost damage, and many other important processes in natural and managed ecosystems.
The energy balance concept can be expressed as:
Energy Inputs = Energy Outputs + Energy Storage
The energy balance of an ecosystem is shown diagrammatically in the figure below. Positive values of the net radiation, Q* mean that the net flow of radiant energy is into the system (i.e., Q* is directed towards the surface); negative values mean the converse (i.e., Q* is directed away from the surface). This convention is used because Q* is regarded as an input to the system. Positive values of the sensible heat density, QH, the latent heat flux density, QE, and the soil heat flux density, QG, mean that energy is flowing out of the system (i.e., away from the surface); negative values mean the converse (i.e., towards the surface). This is because QH, QE and QG are regarded as outputs from the system.
Figure 8.1 Schematic of the energy balance of an ecosystem.
Positive values of the energy storage within the system, mean that the system is accumulating energy; negative values mean that the system is losing energy. Energy may be stored as sensible and latent heat in the canopy air QS, and chemical energy (photosynthesis) QP in the plants. Energy storage as a result of horizontal energy transport (advection) can occur in tall crops (e.g., orchards) and forests, particularly near their borders. The energy balance equation for a crop volume assuming no horizontal energy divergence may, therefore, be written as: (8.1) The energy balance approach is often used to estimate the evaporative water loss, E from ecosystems such as crops and forests. The latent heat flux density QE is the energy used to evaporate water in the stomata (transpiration) and evaporate water in the soil near the soil surface (evaporation from the soil). The sum of transpiration and evaporation from the soil is evapotranspiration.
Net radiation is measured directly by a net radiometer which is usually located 1 to 3 metres above a crop (i.e., shorter vegetation) or 10 m above a forest (i.e., taller vegetation). It may be either a single-differential-thermopile net radiometer with upward- and downward-facing polyethylene domes that transmit shortwave and longwave radiation (as you saw at Totem field) or a four-way net radiometer consisting of upward- and downward-facing pyranometers and pyrgeometers (as shown in Lecture slides).
Soil heat flux density QG is measured by soil heat flux plates usually placed 2 to 5 cm below the soil surface. Thermometers and humidity sensors are used to determine the sensible and latent energy storage within a canopy Qs. Leaf chambers (cuvettes) can be used to measure net CO2 uptake by leaves or the eddy-covariance approach can be used to measure the CO2 uptake by the canopy as a whole. Biochemical energy storage QP can be calculated from the CO2 uptake rate. Canopy energy storage Qs is often neglected because it is generally small compared to Q*.

The net exchange of carbon dioxide (CO2) between terrestrial ecosystems and the atmosphere, called net ecosystem exchange NEE, is the difference between ecosystem respiration Re and gross ecosystem photosynthesis GEP, i.e., (8.1) When NEE is positive (i.e., Re > GEP), the atmosphere gains CO2 and when it’s negative (Re < GEP) the ecosystem gains CO2. Thus, net ecosystem productivity NEP is (8.2) Soil respiration (Rs), which can account for as much as 80% of Re, results in the efflux of CO2 from the soil. Rs is composed of the CO2 produced by microbial decomposition of soil organic matter (SOM) (heterotrophic respiration, Rsh) and by root respiration (autotrophic respiration, Rsa), i.e., (8.3) The autotrophic respiration of stems, branches and leaves accounts for the remainder of Re.
Temperature T, followed by soil moisture, is the most important environmental factor affecting Rs (and all its components). It increases exponentially with T, which is often expressed as (8.4) where Rref is Rs at a reference temperature Tref, usually 10 °C, and Q10 is the relative increase in Rs (or Re) for a 10 K increase in T. Q10 is about 2 in many biological processes but is frequently found to be as much as 3 for Re and Rs. As an example of using Eq. 8.4, assuming Q10 = 2 and Tref = 10 °C, when T = 20 °C, Rs = Rref2[(20-10)/10] = 2 Rref. Can you show that for T = 30 °C, Rs would be 4 times that at Tref?
This sensitivity, which is particularly important in predicting the effects of global warming, depends on the quality (i.e., labile or recalcitrant) and quantity of substrate and thus productivity and soil temperature and moisture. The soil is the largest terrestrial carbon pool. It is particularly vulnerable to warming and its potential loss may result in a `positive feedback’ effect, i.e., increased atmospheric CO2, which could lead to further global warming as a result of the greenhouse effect (Cox et al. 2000). In addition to T and soil moisture, Rsh depends on SOM content and its recalcitrance.
A widely used method of measuring Rs is the closed or static chamber method. In this method, the rate of increase in CO2 concentration in a chamber placed on the soil surface is used to determine the soil CO2 efflux (Livingston and Hutchinson, 1995). This is a good measure of Rs because very little of the respired CO2 accumulates in the soil. The CO2 concentration in the chamber is measured with an infrared gas analyzer (IRGA). If the chamber is kept on the soil for less than 2 minutes, r is almost constant. The SI (Système International d’Unités or International System of Units) is the official unit system in science and therefore mandatory in climatology. This system uses a small number of base units from which other derived units can be obtained. The SI base units are listed in Table 1 and should be used whenever applicable in this course.

The unit for temperature is Kelvin (K, not \(^{\circ} K\)). Temperatures may be also indicated in degree Celsius ( \(^{\circ} C\) ). However, temperature-differences should be referred to as Kelvin (K). The conversion is listed in Equation 12. Note how one Kelvin is equivalent to one degree Celsius, but the units have different zero points.

0 K represents absolute zero, which is the lowest possible temperature: i.e., a complete lack of energy in a system.

e.ge., 100 K is “twice as hot” as 50 K


\(^{\circ} C\) is the freezing point of fresh water at 1 atm (mean atmospheric pressure at sea level).

Celsius is on an interval scale > it has an arbitrary zero value and can take positive or negative values. This prevents relative comparisons between values:

text:
Convective exchange



Convective exchange: describes any process where the flux of an entity (heat, mass or momentum) from or to an object’s surface is driven by convection.
Convection: transfer of heat by moving air. There are two types of convection:

forced convection – depends on external forces

e.g. wind or fan

   free convection - depends on air density differences  (buoyancy)

e.g. warm air rising/cold air falling

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Laminar Boundary Layer



What is the LBL?
It’s the thin layer of air clinging to the surface of objects because of its viscosity. It’s an ‘insulating’ layer. Air moves slowly, parallel to the surface. Transfer is directly across the layer and is by conduction (heat) or diffusion (mass and momentum).






Viscosity is a measure of a fluid’s resistance to flow
However, all objects whether living or not have a thin, still layer of air around them. This layer clings to the object because of the viscosity of air. The layer is referred to as the laminar boundary layer (LBL) or the viscous boundary layer.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Animal microclimate



Microclimate experienced by an animal is determined by the interaction of the animal with its physical environment: interaction via energy and water exchange.
Animals can regulate their energy and water balances with behavioural (hibernating, crowding) and physiological (perspiration, shivering, reducing body temp, growing/shedding fur) mechanisms.
Arctic animals have thick fur coats and some hibernate at reduced body temperature to conserve body heat (e.g. ground squirrels). Desert animals have adapted to lose little water, e. g. the kangaroo rat, which can exhale air at ambient temperature thereby reducing water vapour loss.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Poikilotherms and Homeotherms compared



The temperature of plants and cold blooded animals (poikilotherms) is determined by the environment alone and always responds to changes in that environment (as in the leaf temperature equation in previous lecture).
The deep body temperature of warm blooded animals (homeotherms) is maintained almost constant by physiological mechanisms which alter the rate of heat production by metabolism and dissipation by sensible and latent heat loss.
The hypothalamus has an important temperature sensing
and regulating function, i.e. like a thermostat.
The average temperature for healthy adult humans is 36.8°C (98.2°F)






Cold-blooded animals are the animals that are not capable of regulating their body’s temperature according to the temperature of the surrounding. Thus, they do not have a constant body temperature. Because of this reason, these animals cannot survive in extreme temperatures.
Warm-blooded animals are the animals that are capable of maintaining a nearly constant body temperature irrespective of the temperature of the environment. Warm-blooded animals have several internal mechanisms that help them warm up in colder areas and cool down in warmer areas. The control is mostly obtained by regulating their metabolic rates.
The terms are catchalls for three different aspects of metabolism: the way an animal heats his body, the consistency of the animal’s body temperature and the consistency of an animal’s metabolic rate.
In general, coldblooded animals derive heat from external sources, and their temperature and metabolic rate vary greatly. 
Conversely, warmblooded animals heat their bodies internally, and they have relatively stable temperatures and metabolic rates.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Poikilotherms and Homeotherms compared



Poikilotherms, such as lizards, tortoises, and bees appear to prefer environments where exposure to solar radiation raises body temperature to between 30 and 35 ºC, close to the range in which homeotherms operate.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Energy balance of animals



The energy balance equation for an animal can be expressed as
Q* + QM = QH + QE + QG +QF + △Qs
where all terms are expressed as a flux per unit of the total body surface area in W m-2 and:
-Q* is the net radiation gain
-QM is the metabolic heat production within the animal
-QH and QE are the sensible and latent heat losses, respectively, to the atmosphere
-QG is the heat conducted to the ground
-QF is heat loss in feces and urine

△Qs is the rate of heat storage as a result of temperature change of the animal’s body (~0 W m-2 in the case of a homeotherm).







In general, coldblooded animals derive heat from external sources, and their temperature and metabolic rate vary greatly. 
Conversely, warmblooded animals heat their bodies internally, and they have relatively stable temperatures and metabolic rates.

Daytime
A difficulty in calculating Q* in sunny conditions: direct solar radiation strikes only a fraction of the total body surface, while absorbed longwave irradiance and longwave emittance occur over most of the body surface.
The ratio of the projected or shadow area (Ap) of the animal to the total surface area (A) of animal is the animal shape factor (S). It is used to ‘weight’ the direct beam solar irradiance (i. e. the flux density on a surface perpendicular to the sun’s rays) when calculating K↓ for the animal’s total body surface.

When an animal is standing, conduction losses (through the feet) are small. However, these losses can be large when the animal is lying down.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Adiabatic processes



Even though the heat content of the parcel is conserved the parcel T changes. This is because the air pressure (p) decreases with height and the volume of the parcel changes.
On ascent p decreases, the parcel expands and the work done causes the parcel T to drop. The reverse is true if the parcel sinks - it compresses and warms.
The rate at which it cools or warms is a constant (~1K 100 m-1, or 10 K km-1) as long as it stays dry. This known as the dry adiabatic lapse rate (DALR or Γd)






An adiabatic process is one in which no heat is gained or lost by the system
WIKI: When the pressure applied on a parcel of air is reduced, the air in the parcel is allowed to expand; as the volume increases, the temperature falls as its internal energy decreases
WIKI: When a parcel of air descends, the pressure on the parcel increases. Due to this increase in pressure, the parcel’s volume decreases and its temperature increases as work is done on the parcel of air, thus increasing its internal energy, which manifests itself by a rise in the temperature of that mass of air
(with a smaller volume, molecules are compressed and are flying around faster and have higher kinetic energy, and thus a higher temperature, while as the volume increases, molecules are more spread out and move around more slowly and therefore have lower temperature).

It is key to understand the difference between 2 types of lapse rates:
environmental lapse rate (ELR) – this is the actual distribution of T with height in the Atmosphere – found by plotting the T values with height if you send a thermometer aloft and measure along the way.
process lapse rate (DALR or SALR) – the way the T of a parcel of air changes as it is physically moved through the Atmosphere.

section: Streamlines indicate the mean flow direction
text:
Streamlines indicate the mean flow direction


Airflow around a solid barrier

Three zones can be identified :

Displacement zone: the air is displaced upward and accelerated as it moves over the barrier.
Cavity (quiet) zone: mean wind speed is low and the effect of the turbulent wake flow from the top of the barrier is small.
Wake zone: mean wind is reduced and
turbulence is increased






As oncoming flow (A) approaches a building the mean flow streamlines are displaced, due to the build-up of a positive pressure perturbation on the windward face (see displacement zone B, Figure 4.4). Air diverges vertically and laterally to flow over and around the building. The flow diverges in all directions from this point: up over the roof, around the sides and down the front. negative pressure perturbation on the roof, side walls and leeward face of the building which create suction and induce air to circulate in the reverse direction to the main flow. Some of the air deflects down the face of the building to the ground. There it streams away from the face and back towards the approach flow, undercutting it and causing it to separate from the ground upwind and forms a standing eddy vortex near the base. Behind the building the flow structure is complex; flow separation dominates, as it streams past the rear edges of the side walls and roof leaving a suction zone in the lee of the building. This is the cavity zone C, which is part of the overall wake zone D, of the building (Figure 4.4). Immediately behind the corner of a building the lower surface pressure causes flow to recirculate against the approach flow creating a a vortex.. In the wake mean wind is reduced & turbulence is increased. Momentum – force the wind exerts on crops and trees. This is force per unit ground area is called shear stress (τ, N m-2). 
Upwind of the building (I), the profile is in equilibrium with the underlying surface. At location (II) the profile responds by accelerating, due to the confluence of the flow in the displacement zone, as it ‘squeezes’ over the top of the building.  Closer to the roof surface, in the cavity zone, there is a sharp decrease of speed in the zone of lower pressure above the roof, and counter-flow, especially immediately adjacent to its windward edge. Behind the building (III), the wind profile shows return flow and a marked velocity deficit (shelter) in the cavity. At location (IV), flow starts to restore the wind profile to its undisturbed state, however the velocity deficit persists for some distance (x), decaying at a rate of about x-1/5 and fading out by about x = 15H.

Types of frost



We distinguish between radiative and advective frosts: 
•Radiative frost results from radiative cooling (longwave energy loss to the sky and space) at night under clear conditions. Various ways of combating it. 
•Advective frost happens when an cold air mass on a large scale invades a location. This is usually associated with a weather system. Difficult to protect against. 
Frosts induced by radiative cooling during the growing season can be critical for bud development, regeneration and survival of plants.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Radiative frost



With radiative frost, the longwave energy loss not only cools the surface but also reduces the temperature of the air near the surface through convection. The air at higher levels is less affected by the surface cooling. 
Therefore, radiative frost is usually accompanied by a temperature inversion, i.e., an increase in air temperature with height.

How wind machines work 



Wind machines rely on the presence of a temperature inversion. Inversion strength is the increase in air temperature per unit height (°C m-1). 
Under clear conditions, when a radiative frost is most likely to occur, an inversion is usually strong, ranging from 2 - 6°C/10 m. 
The inversion indicates larger heat concentration at higher levels. This heat energy can be used to warm the air and plants at lower heights by mechanically mixing the air.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Oasis effect



Advectively driven QE due to a wet patch existing within a larger dry environment (desert oasis, urban park, irrigated field).
This contributes sensible heat to boost QE > Q. In some cases QE can be 1.5 to 2 times Q.







Advective effect: The oasis effect This apparently anomalous situation is explained by the fact that the atmosphere supplies sensible heat to the surface because the oasis is cooler than the regional air in which it is embedded. Therefore there is a continual air-to-oasis inversion temperature gradient driving a downward directed heat flux, and the process is aided by air mass subsidence over the oasis. (Note that the reversal of QH gives the oasis a negative Bowen ratio.) Figure 5.5 shows the average daily energy balance components in June following the irrigation in late May. For the first half of June an ‘oasis effect’ is clearly evident; evapotranspiration exceeds the net radiation, and QH is directed towards the crop. During this period the average Bowen ratio is about -0·25, and the ratio QE/Q* is approximately 1·5. However, by the middle of June soil moisture starts to become restricted, the surface resistance (rc) increases, and evaporation rates decrease. Since Q* remains relatively constant this requires an adjustment by QH. By 25 June the Bowen ratio is +1·0, and QE/Q* is about 0·5. In the absence of further irrigation or precipitation the energy balance would return to a semi-arid type.
Many other ‘oasis-effect’ advective situations can be envisaged. In each of the following examples a cool, moist surface is dominated by larger- scale warmer, drier surroundings: a lake in an area with a dry summer climate; a glacier in a mountain valley; an isolated snow patch; an urban park; an isolated tree in a street or on open, bare ground. In each case we may expect evaporation to proceed at an increased rate compared with that from an extensive area of the same composition, and it is quite possible that the energy required to accomplish this will exceed the local radiative surplus.

‘Clothesline’ effect
Advective effects of drier air penetrating through a vegetation canopy. Especially seen at crop and forest edge borders. Analogy of the drying effect of air through a clothesline of wet laundry. Enhanced QE of edge plants often causes them to be stunted, open to disease, and soil moisture is drawn down.






If the air entering the crop from the right is warm and dry it will increase both the heat supply, and the vapour pressure gradient between the transpiring leaves and the crop air. The net result is to enhance the evaporation rate and hence to more rapidly deplete the soil moisture close to the stand border. Further into the crop the air cools down and acquires moisture, thus causing it to adjust to the more typical conditions within the stand. At the edge of crops the soil moisture depletion, crop desiccation, greater wind damage, and greater exposure to new plant pests and disease commonly combine to stunt crop growth for a few metres in from the border.

Hydrologic cycle



It controls the distribution of the Earth’s water as it evaporates from land masses and water bodies, condenses, precipitates, and returns to those land masses and water bodies.

Increasing photon flux above this point results in a proportional increase in photosynthetic rate, represented by a linear relationship between photon flux and photosynthetic rate. We know that these different components of the C cycle are changing over time. FF increasing &LUC Both ocean and land CO2 sinks increased since the 1960s, roughly in line with the atmospheric increase, While at the moment clearly ecosystems are helping us deal with atmospheric CO2, Any significant decrease in these carbon sinks means that we’re going to have to work harder in the future from keeping GHGs from accumulating in the atmosphere. Net ecosystem exchange (NEE) is the difference between ecosystem respiration (Re) and gross ecosystem photosynthesis (GEP) – commonly used by micrometeorologists.

Reflection

Cloud tops are most significant. Clouds reflect 40 to 80% of the short-wave radiation incident upon them, the average is 55%*.

We call this the cloud albedo, hence the ratio of the amount of solar (short-wave) radiation reflected by a body to the amount incident upon it.







Reflection from clouds is really important! This is why the earth looks so bright from space. Clouds viewed from the sides or above are also very white (an indicator that they are reflecting all wavelengths of visible light).

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Absorption in the atmosphere



The atmosphere is a selective absorber of solar radiation.
The most significant absorbing substances are:
Water vapour: important for λ > 0.8 μm, absorption bands are at 1.1, 1.45, 1.95 μm
O2 and O3: important for λ < 0.3 μm
CO2: important for λ > 2.5 μm
The atmosphere is quite transparent near λmax = 0.48 μm where the intensity of solar radiation is greatest.






As well as reflection of radiation from clouds, the atmosphere also ABSORBS solar radiation.

title: Atmospheric Environments
text:
Scattering


increasing particle size
Illustration: Georgia State University.

Scattering is a process like reflection in which incident light is diffused in all directions by the smallest gaseous molecules and aerosols (e.g. smoke). Scattering creates the blue sky color and red sunsets. If particles are larger (e.g. water droplets) the sky is hazy and whiter.
Together these processes reduce the solar radiation getting to the ground and diffuse the beam so that it arrives from all parts of the sky hemisphere.






Scattering is usually divided into two types: Rayleigh scattering is caused by gas molecules and tends to scatter in all directions with the shortest wavelengths scattered most (hence blue light giving rise to the blue sky) Mie scattering is associated with much large solid or liquid particles (water droplets, smoke, sea salt haze) scatter all wavelength equally and mostly in a forward direction. Because all wavelengths are scattered equally the result is a “white” appearance to the sky.

If light is not reflected, absorbed or scattered it must be transmitted to the ground. The Greek letter tau is used to denote the proportion of light reaching the ground compared to that at the outer edge of the atmosphere. In Vancouver we typically have about 70% of solar radiation at the outer edge of the atmosphere reaching the ground.

Thermopile


Solar radiation (K↓ = S + D) is measured by a pyranometer. It has glass domes (transmit only short-wave radiation, prevent conduction / convection) and a thermopile (measures the temperature rise of the absorbing black surface).
Pyranometer
Two glass domes
Photos: A. Christen





Inside the double glass dome (to prevent convection and conduction) there is a black absorber disk (the sensing element), which is made of a black carbon with a high absorptivity. The temperature rise of the sensing element due to short-wave irradiance is measured relatively to the (more constant) body temperature of the pyranometer. A thermopile (array of thermocouples) measures the temperature difference, which creates a voltage and then is measured by the data logger. The black carbon would be also sensitive to long-wave radiation, but the glass dome filters out the long-wave emission. A double glass dome reduces heating of the inner dome (long-wave emission of the dome).

Recall - heat vs. temperature



Heat – the thermal energy content of a body. Expressed as energy per unit mass or per unit volume of a substance. (i.e. J kg-1 or J m-3)
Temperature – the ability of a body to transfer thermal energy to another body. It is a measure of the random kinetic energy of its molecules.

Warming / cooling rates
Notice that the higher C the smaller is the rate of temperature change. For example, a wet soil (high C) has a ‘conservative’ thermal climate (it responds sluggishly to heat input or output). Conversely a dry soil (low C) is ‘flashy’ becoming hot by day and cold by night.
